Funders for this research include University of Tehran, Shahid Chamran University of Ahvaz. Our news editors obtained a quote from the research from Shahid Chamran University Ahvaz,“ Groups...
text:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Middle East
Daily \-- Current study results on Gram-Negative Bacteria - Aeromonas
hydrophila have been published. According to news reporting originating from
Ahwaz, Iran, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "The outer membrane
protein of Aeromonas hydrophila is a potential candidate for vaccine
development. In this study, after cloning and expression of ompTS, 270 common
carp, weighing 44 +/- 5.7 g divided into five groups, were injected
intraperitoneally twice with 3-week intervals."

Funders for this research include University of Tehran, Shahid Chamran
University of Ahvaz.

Our news editors obtained a quote from the research from Shahid Chamran
University Ahvaz, "Groups included the following: PBS, PBS plus Freund's
adjuvant, recombinant protein, recombinant protein plus Freund's adjuvant and
20 fish as negative control. Two weeks after the second injection, 30 fish of
each group were challenged with a dose of 2 x LD50 of Aeromonas hydrophila and
RPS was measured. The antibody level was measured using ELISA test. The
protection of recombinant protein in the immunized fish with and without
adjuvant, respectively, was about 82.61% and 78.26% (the protection of
recombinant protein electroeluted from an SDS-PAGE with and without adjuvant,
respectively, was about 78.62% and 69.57%). The average of antibody level in
recombinant protein with and without adjuvant was significantly higher than
the PBS group (p < .05)."

According to the news editors, the research concluded: "The ability of
recombinant ompTS to increase the antibody level and to protect the fish from
challenge by A. hydrophila demonstrated that recombinant ompTS protein
injection can be used to immunize common carp against A. hydrophila
infection."

For more information on this research see: Investigation On Protective Effect
of Recombinant Protein (Ompts) of Aeromonas Hydrophila In Common Carp
(Cyprinus Carpio). _Aquaculture Research_ , 2020;():. _Aquaculture Research_
can be contacted at: Wiley, 111 River St, Hoboken 07030-5774, NJ, USA. (Wiley-
Blackwell - <http://www.wiley.com/>; Aquaculture Research \-
<http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/journal/10.1111/(ISSN)1365-2109>)

The news editors report that additional information may be obtained by
contacting S. Eftekharmanavi, Shahid Chamran University Ahvaz, Faculty of
Veterinary Medicine, Aquat Anim Hlth & Dis, Ahwaz 4168675160, Iran. Additional
authors for this research include R. Peyghan, M. Soltani and M.G. Najafabadi.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is:
<https://doi.org/10.1111/are.14682>. This DOI is a link to an online
electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your
direct source for a journal article and its citation.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around
the world.)

title: Findings from Shahid Chamran University Ahvaz Reveals New Findings on Aeromonas hydrophila [Investigation On Protective Effect of Recombinant Protein (Ompts) of Aeromonas Hydrophila In Common Carp (Cyprinus Carpio)]: Gram-Negative Bacteria - Aeromonas hydrophila
html:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Middle East Daily -- Current study results on Gram-Negative Bacteria - Aeromonas hydrophila have been published. According to news reporting originating from Ahwaz, Iran, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, “The outer membrane protein of Aeromonas hydrophila is a potential candidate for vaccine development. In this study, after cloning and expression of ompTS, 270 common carp, weighing 44 +/- 5.7 g divided into five groups, were injected intraperitoneally twice with 3-week intervals.”

Funders for this research include University of Tehran, Shahid Chamran University of Ahvaz.

Our news editors obtained a quote from the research from Shahid Chamran University Ahvaz, “Groups included the following: PBS, PBS plus Freund’s adjuvant, recombinant protein, recombinant protein plus Freund’s adjuvant and 20 fish as negative control. Two weeks after the second injection, 30 fish of each group were challenged with a dose of 2 x LD50 of Aeromonas hydrophila and RPS was measured. The antibody level was measured using ELISA test. The protection of recombinant protein in the immunized fish with and without adjuvant, respectively, was about 82.61% and 78.26% (the protection of recombinant protein electroeluted from an SDS-PAGE with and without adjuvant, respectively, was about 78.62% and 69.57%). The average of antibody level in recombinant protein with and without adjuvant was significantly higher than the PBS group (p < .05).”

According to the news editors, the research concluded: “The ability of recombinant ompTS to increase the antibody level and to protect the fish from challenge by A. hydrophila demonstrated that recombinant ompTS protein injection can be used to immunize common carp against A. hydrophila infection.”

For more information on this research see: Investigation On Protective Effect of Recombinant Protein (Ompts) of Aeromonas Hydrophila In Common Carp (Cyprinus Carpio). Aquaculture Research, 2020;():. Aquaculture Research can be contacted at: Wiley, 111 River St, Hoboken 07030-5774, NJ, USA. (Wiley-Blackwell - http://www.wiley.com/; Aquaculture Research - http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/journal/10.1111/(ISSN)1365-2109)

The news editors report that additional information may be obtained by contacting S. Eftekharmanavi, Shahid Chamran University Ahvaz, Faculty of Veterinary Medicine, Aquat Anim Hlth & Dis, Ahwaz 4168675160, Iran. Additional authors for this research include R. Peyghan, M. Soltani and M.G. Najafabadi.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.1111/are.14682. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around the world.)
